intro: Lappula echinata var. consanguinea, commonly known as the hairy lappula, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and showy, yellowish or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and can be found in meadows, roadsides, and wastelands. Its fruit is a capsule that dehisces to release small, wind-dispersed seeds. The variety consanguinea is distinguished by its more hairy stems and leaves compared to the typical form.
